characters: A STREAM OF CRYSTAL BLUE WATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a MAN GASPING softly.     Rhythmically. A LUMINOUS PALE SHAPE slowly forms out of the searing whiteness. Gradually we realize we're moving across the ALABASTER BODY of a WOMAN. Her skin translucent.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WOMAN'S FACE
dialogues.text: Ethereal.   Her eyes closed.     Her face lifeless.   The ...her eyes open. She looks straight at us with unseeing pale blue eyes. This is ANNA (late 20s). We pull back. PAUL (30s) makes love to Anna. Their movements perfunctory. Passionless. He turns to look at her. Realizes she's not there. He suddenly stops. Rolls off her. Sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna leans down and picks up her RED SLIP from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to enjoy it. Now it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.    Frustrated.   Lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's like fucking a corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul immediately realizes he's gone too far.      Turns t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.   I'm sorry.   That was--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gets out of bed. Walks towards the bathroom.       P puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the fogged shower partition we see the blurred ghostly figure of Anna. Paul walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna. I'm sorry. That was a stupid thing to say.   But you know sometimes... sometimes it's like you're not here anymore. Like you're somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this about us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her head bowed as she lets the water wash over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want us to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna doesn't move.    We sense the emptiness inside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes her eyes.    Forces herself to reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy.

dialogues.speaker: A DROP OF BLOOD
dialogues.text: falls into the water.   Then another drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her nose is bleeding. She touches her lips. Looks impassively at the blood on her fingertips. The SOUND OF WATER carries into the next scene...

dialogues.speaker: A STREAM OF CRYSTAL BLUE WATER
dialogues.text: A MAN'S HANDS penetrate the water. Thin and elegant. Perfectly manicured. Turning slowly as he washes them meticulously. He picks up a crisply folded white towel. Dries his hands carefully. Snaps on white latex gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful morning. We move through a tranquil cemetery. Pastoral and idyllic. Dappled light falls through old trees onto statues of grieving angels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A path leads to an old well-kept house. Amongst a blaze o violet tulips we see a sign: Eliot Deane. Funeral Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun streams into an elegant wood-panelled room. The Funeral Director, ELIOT DEANE (40s) guides MRS. AYRES (70s) past caskets tastefully arranged on faux-marble pedestals. He's a serene man. Quiet and professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Antique Carlisle. Solid cherry. (strokes the wood lovingly) Hand rubbed satin finish. Tufted sovereign interior. Eternal-Rest adjustable mattress with matching pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures to a metal casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or perhaps the Aegean? Solid bronze exterior. Hand brushed finish with Grecian bronze highlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Antique Carlisle. Definitely the Antique Carlisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writes in his notebook) Excellent choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ayres caresses the soft velvet trimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An antique coffin for an antique lady. We suit each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now about the service.   Would you like a private visitation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ayres is miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ayres?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Yes. A private visitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deane? What happens when we die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's different every time.   Each person dies in their own way.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANNA'S CAR
dialogues.text: Anna drives past the strip malls of a small suburban town in a GREEN TOYOTA. On the dashboard a KITSCHY BOBBLEHEAD DOLL nods its head from side to side. Anna pulls up to a red light. Glances across at the other cars. We see the vacant faces of COMMUTERS staring blankly into space. The light changes. Anna hasn't noticed. The car behind her HONKS in frustration. She quickly pulls out... ... just as a SUV turns in front of her. She slams on her brakes. Hard. Missing the SUV by inches. The DRIVER screams at her. His face contorted in ugly rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna locks her car.   Heads towards the main building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classes have started. JACK (11), a serious looking boy, walks through a silent corridor. Up ahead two OLDER BOYS, a TALL KID and a KID with ACNE, push a GEEKY BOY against a locker. Jack tries to pass by unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.   Jack-off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks faster. The two Older Boys set off after him. He darts into a corridor. Ducks into an empty classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack waits anxiously by the door. It looks like he's lost the bullies. Then a sudden rustling noise makes him jump. He turns. TINY CHICKS huddle in a plastic incubator on a table. Jack moves over to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear me Jack-off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack swivels round. The Tall Kid walks towards him as the Acne Kid guards the door. Jack doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must be deaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deaf Jack-off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack ignores them.   Irritating the Tall Kid even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't fucking speak either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes Jack against the table, toppling the incubator. Panicked, the CHICKS scatter across the surface. Just then the door opens. Anna walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances at the Older Boys then at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing Miss Bryant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing? The incubator didn't just fall by itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Older Boys stare at Jack.    Waiting for his reaction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tripped.   It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks at Jack carefully.    She knows he's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Older Boys) Show's over. Get to your classes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. Help me clear up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack doesn't hear her. He's mesmerized by a SOLITARY CHICK standing motionless in the corner of the incubator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna reaches in.   Tenderly picks up the chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   The poor thing's just scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School's over. Anna listlessly corrects a stack of exercise books. She can't focus. Pulls out a BOTTLE OF PILLS. Shakes a pill into her hand. Swallows it dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul works with half a dozen COLLEAGUES around a large conference table covered with documents and thick files. He reaches across to a pizza box. It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.   Who took the last pepperoni?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PREPPY GUY slides across another pizza box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  Broccoli. (lifts out a slice) Who the fuck ordered broccoli?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEAL, a thin pallid guy, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's just disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with vegetarian pizza?   It's healthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pizza isn't supposed to be healthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul glances at his watch. Suddenly realizes the time. He quickly picks up his cell phone. Heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ordering in another pizza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.    With wheatgrass and alfalfa sprouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. Smart asses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul walks into the corridor dialling his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's cell phone rings as she closes her locker. She fishes it out from her bag as she heads to the door. Checks the ID. Hesitates. Then takes the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul cups his cell.    Worried he'll be overheard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi baby.    I'm really sorry about this morning.    I fucked up. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steps into an empty corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still on for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's anxious.    We sense he's hiding something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Anna.    It took me weeks to get the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can change it to Thursday--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.     It has to be tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul tries hard to cover his nervousness.   Forces a smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Don't worry. I just need... I just want us to have dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite Paul's reassurances Anna is clearly worried now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hesitates.    Lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Anna.    Everything's going to be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna slips her phone back into her bag as she walks through the deserted corridor. Her high heels echo loudly in the eerie quietness. Suddenly one of the fluorescent ceiling lights behind her blows out with a loud WHUMPH. Anna starts. Turns. WHUMPH. The next light dies. Anna quickens her step. The lights go off one by one. The darkness quickly creeping up behind her. There's only one light still on as she reaches the exit. She looks up. The light flickers. But then strangely stays on. Bathing her in a cold pool of light. Anna's unsettled. She turns and frantically pushes the door. It doesn't open. She pushes hard with both hands. Nothing. It's locked. She turns back slowly. The darkness around her impenetrable. Almost viscous. She reaches out... ... her hand DISAPPEARS into the thick blackness.     Ann snatches her hand back. Stares at it. Then we hear the sound of SLOW FOOTSTEPS.    Moving deliberately towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice echoes down the silent corridor.   She glimpses something move in the blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is someone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK SHAPE materializes inside the darkness. Silent. Brooding. Anna can't move. Terrified. Suddenly the corridor's flooded with a BLINDING WHITE LIGHT. Anna's dazzled. Shades her eyes with her hand.     As she tentatively pulls her hand away... ...it's only Jack.   His hand on the light switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I scare you Miss Bryant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack moves over to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gently pushes against the door.    The door slowly ope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, still shaken, walks with Jack towards the parking l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom's picking me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my birthday. We're going to MacDonald's. Then on Saturday my mom's taking me to Busch Gardens. We're going to ride the Alpengeist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continually voted one of the top ten roller coaster rides in America, the Alpengeist is a breathtaking avalanche of adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries to keep a straight-face) I didn't know the park was open yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom's friends with the manager. They're opening it specially for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows he's lying again.     Smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.    It will be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach Anna's car.    Stand in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. Those boys.    Do they bother you a lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack hesitates.    Then slowly nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you can always talk to me about it if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.   Anna's clearly worried about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't need a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack shakes his head.    Anna glances at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.   I better run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go to a funeral.   My old piano teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sudden interest) Can I come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Jack.   Funerals are very private affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been to a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be appropriate Jack. Anyway wouldn't your mom worry about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she would. I'll see you tomorrow in class. Have a wonderful birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack nods disappointed.   Anna watches him walk away then gets in her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna slips her key into the ignition. Loud music suddenly blares from the car radio. She switches it off. Squeezes the bridge of her nose. She pulls out a bottle of pills from her bag. It's empty. She rummages in the glove compartment. Finds another bottle. Empty. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits on the bench. Watches Anna drive away. Then unzips his backpack. Something moves inside. A strange jerky movement. Jack closes the backpack. Glances up and down the empty street. Then walks away on his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steps out of the Pharmacy. As she washes down a pill with a bottle of water she notices a small Hair Salon. Looks critically at herself in the Pharmacy window. Anna moves over to the Salon. Reaches for the door handle... then hesitates. She's about to walk away when the Salon door suddenly opens. Anna smiles shyly as a freshly COIFFURED WOMAN politely holds the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna leans back against a washbasin.    Her neck tightly cradled against the white porcelain.    The light's harsh and not particularly flattering. She    closes her eyes. Behind her the HANDS of a HAIRDRESSER   in latex gloves begin to rinse dye from Anna's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startling white. A stream of water flows into the sink. Then after a moment the spiralling clear water gradually turns a deep crimson red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna closes the front door behind her. She smiles as she catches her reflection in the hallway mirror. Her hair a dark vibrant red. Just then, from another room, we hear an OLD WOMAN'S hacking cough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna?   Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's mother, BEATRICE (50s), sits in bed, knitting with swift, violent precision. The bedside table's stacked with medication. She's clearly been bed-ridden for some time. An electric wheelchair in the corner of the room. Anna appears at the door. Beatrice scrutinizes her for a second. Then returns to her knitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna moves to the beside table.   Picks up a dirty plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor said--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor's an idiot. He doesn't know what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sighs. Trying hard not to let her Mother provoke her. Beatrice glances up. Anna avoids her look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do it? Today of all days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I done wrong this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna goes to the window.   Draws back the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've forgotten haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I haven't forgotten.   The service isn't till six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you've got plenty of time to wash it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's permanent. You can't wash it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then dye it back. You can't show up at the funeral looking like that. Like some prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't look--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't argue with me. Why are you constantly arguing with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna bites her tongue.    Heads to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do the washing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheets need changing.    They haven't been changed in months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed them Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna goes to the cupboard.    Takes out clean sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't here Monday. You never sleep at home anymore. What if something happened to me in the middle of the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is going to happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat lot of good she is. I wouldn't have to pay for a Nurse if my only daughter wasn't living in sin with that lawyer of hers. Doing God knows what. They always leave you in the end. You'll see. Just like your father--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough Mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna dumps the sheets on the bed. As she turns to leave Beatrice's hand darts out and grabs Anna's wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.     Go and cry to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pulls herself free.   Moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and bitch to Paul about your mean old mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warm intimate room. Peaceful. Rows of chairs filled with ELDERLY MOURNERS. Eliot stands respectfully beside a casket. FATHER GRAHAM (50s) reads at a lectern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have entrusted our brother James Hutton to God's mercy in sure and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, in a black dress, walks quickly along the gravel driveway. She stops. Stares out over the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...certain hope of the resurrection to eternal life through our Lord Jesus Christ, who died and rose again for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna slips into the back of the room. Eliot leads MRS. HUTTON (60s) to the body of her husband, JAMES HUTTON (70S), lying in the casket. Mrs. Hutton touches a bouquet of white roses by the casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White roses. They were his favorite. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just seemed appropriate somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks so peaceful. As if he's only sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna approaches Mrs. Hutton.   She doesn't notice Eliot watching her carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hutton.    I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Anna. You were always his favorite student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles awkwardly.     Uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.   She sends her condolences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look tired dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   I'm fine. Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can see in her eyes that everything's not fine. Mrs. Hutton nods, then turns to greet another MOURNER. Anna steps nervously up to the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Hutton lies peacefully amongst the velvet trimming. Suddenly his LIPS PART... as he GASPS SOFTLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steps back terrified. Stares at Hutton. His face serene again. It must have been her imagination. She glances up quickly. Embarrassed. Eliot's still observing her.     He nods to her cordially

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spartan room at the top of the house. Eliot carefully pins a POLAROID of Hutton lying in a coffin to the wall. Next to Hutton's photograph, we briefly glimpse the edge of ANOTHER POLAROID. Eliot stares intently at Hutton's image for a moment, then takes off his jacket and moves to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's by her car rummaging in a bag for her keys. Getting increasingly frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna suddenly looses it. Angrily dumps the contents of her bag onto the driveway. She kneels down. Grabs the keys. Throws the rest of her things back into the bag. She stands. Leans against the car. She looks weary. She glances up at the sky desperately trying to hold back her tears. Black storm clouds gather on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna brusquely wipes away her eyes with the back of her hand. Pulls herself together. Angry with herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot watches intently as Anna drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits at a window table. It's raining hard outside. He glances at his watch then nervously checks his pockets. Pulls out a RING BOX. He looks at it for a moment then slips it back into his pocket. As he refills his glass, Anna appears outside holding her raincoat above her head. She stares at Paul for a moment through the window marbled with rain. Paul suddenly notices Anna at the window.   He starts. Spills some of his red wine on his shirt. CLOSE on the red stain. It unfurls like a flower. Spreading out over the white material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul dabs the stain with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scared the life out of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna laughs as she sits down.   Paul looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. It's just very... red. I mean it's not really you is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITER appears at the table before Anna can reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.    We'll have the duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?    You always have the duck here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up the menu) I don't always have the duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul shrugs. Pours Anna some wine as she looks through the menu. The Waiter taps his pen on his pad impatiently. Anna sighs. Puts the menu aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have the duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul smiles as the Waiter leaves. Anna tries to ignore him. But after a second she can't help smiling back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The duck is very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's smile broadens. The tension between them broken for the moment. Paul reaches across. Touches her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not argue tonight.    OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna takes a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the bottle.    Checks the label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And looks very expensive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the special occasion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's momentarily thrown. He tries to cover it by rearranging his napkin. Anna notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly very serious) Actually there is something I need to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Anna's nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been offered a transfer to head office in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks down.   Stares at her hands on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll mean more work of course. More responsibility. A lot of changes. But it's an incredible opportunity. I'd be crazy to turn it down. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...well I've been thinking. Maybe it's time for us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul pauses as he reaches inside his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) You're going to leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's stunned.   Speechless.   Before he can say anythin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could've just told me this morning. You didn't need to buy me off with an expensive meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul reaches for her hand.     Anna gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you lie to me? You promised everything was going to be OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. Anna. You've got it all wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not being ridiculous. Why do you always talk to me like I'm a small child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if talking to a small child) Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? There you go again.      Do you know how irritating that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Can't we just have one fucking meal without arguing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other DINERS turn and stare at them. Paul glances at them embarrassed. Anna doesn't notice. Upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down, everyone's watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK YOU!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. You know that?      Just like your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm nothing like my mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna grabs her coat.   Pushes her way through the restaur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not running after you this time Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's suddenly aware that everyone's looking at him. He quickly sits down. Drains his glass of wine. Furious.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANNA'S CAR
dialogues.text: Anna closes the car door.   It's still raining hard outsi Her hair, perfect minutes ago, is now bedraggled. Her mak up's running. She places her hands on the steering wheel. Trying desperately to pull herself together. Suddenly. THUMP. Anna jumps. Turns. Paul's at the car window. He thumps the glass again. Anna hits the locks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul grabs the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna. Open the door. Please. I want you to come with me. I want to...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANNA'S CAR
dialogues.text: Anna can't hear him above the sound of the RAIN HAMMERING onto the car. She shakes her head. Puts the car in drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stumbles aside as Anna's car pulls away. She stops at the parking lot exit a short distance away.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANNA'S CAR
dialogues.text: Anna looks up into the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ON REARVIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: Paul stands forlornly in the rain.      Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates.       For a moment we think she might go b to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but then Anna pulls out and drives away. Leaving Paul alone in the parking lot. The rain pounding the asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANNA'S CAR. HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Anna peers through the blurred windshield as the wipers battle with the TORRENTIAL DOWNPOUR. A LARGE TRUCK plows past menacingly on the rain-slicked highway. Anna's still upset. She wipes away her tears. On the dashboard the kitschy doll bobs its head from side to side. Anna picks up her cell phone. Glances down as she dials a number. She looks up... a WHITE VAN with black tinted windows cuts in front of he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna swerves into the next lane.      We hear the blaring horn from the car behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into rear-view mirror) OK. OK. I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cell phone connects.      We hear Paul's answering ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? You home yet? Can you pick up?      I just don't want it to end like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna drops the phone into her bag on the passenger seat. Wipes away the mist on the inside of the glass. A TRACTOR TRAILER shudders past loaded with metal pipes.

dialogues.speaker: ON METAL PIPES
dialogues.text: The badly loaded pipes BANG OMINOUSLY against each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness.   A bright light comes on. CLOSE ON a MAN'S HANDS. Turning slowly under a stream of crystal blue water. We pull back. Eliot dries his hands. Opens a cabinet. Takes out a pair of latex gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room. Tall vaulted ceilings. White tiles. Soft morning light seeps in from a small round window set high on one wall. The room is silent. Still. Like a chapel. In the semi-darkness we see a BODY on a porcelain slab covered with a white sheet. We hear a key turn in a lock. Then another lock.       Th room's suddenly flooded with a harsh white light. Eliot steps inside the room. He takes off his jacket. Carefully places it on a coat-hanger. Puts on a pale blue smock then snaps on the latex gloves. His every move meticulous. Measured. Like a ritual. Eliot walks over to the slab, his surgery clogs softly clacking against the tiled floor. He looks at the slab for a moment then slowly pulls the sheet away revealing... ANNA'S BODY. Pale and lifeless. An ugly gash above her eyebrow. Cracked violet lips. A rip in her black dress soaked with a dark stain. She's only wearing one shoe. Eliot gently takes off the watch from her stiff wrist. Places it inside a brown paper bag. Eases off the shoe. Picks up a scalpel from a tray of instruments on a steel trolley. Delicately slices open her dress. Peels it off. He's about to cut the straps of her RED SLIP when... Anna OPENS HER EYES. She looks straight at us with unseeing pale blue eyes. Strangely Eliot's not surprised.   He calmly steps back. Watches her carefully. Anna's eyes slowly focus on Eliot.     She's groggy.   Co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She talks with difficulty.       Her breathe labored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a funeral home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's vacant eyes widen in shock. She struggles to sit up but she can't even raise her head. Her body stiff. Rigid. Eliot speaks to her calmly. Soothingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a car accident. It was raining. You hit a truck loaded with metal pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks fearfully at the bloodied dress in Eliot's hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were pronounced dead eight hours ago. Your blood no longer circulates through your body. Your brain cells are slowly dying. Your body's already decomposing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot looks at her sadly for a moment. He places the bloodied dress on the trolley. Then picks up a document. Holds it up for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Anna's death certificate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your death certificate. Cause of death. Massive internal trauma. Time of death. 8.23PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were dead on arrival. The attending physician signed here... (points to document) ...at 9.45 last night. I picked up your body from the hospital morgue at 12.10 this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna stares with horror at her death certificate, then at Eliot. He looks away. It pains him to see her so distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot picks up a sponge from the trolley.   Wets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot delicately washes Anna's face. She doesn't flinch as he dabs the wound above her eye brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me! Why are you touching me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm preparing your body. You have to look beautiful for your funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot sighs wearily.   As if he'd had this conversation many times before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all say the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Maybe you should rest now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot peels off his latex gloves and heads for the door. As he hangs his pale blue smock on the peg he turns and looks at Anna for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights go off. O.S. the door clicks shut as it locks automatically behind Eliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be dead. It's just a nightmare. I'll wake up soon. Wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul wakes up. Badly hung-over. Still in his clothes. Sunlight streams into the room. Blinding him. He reaches across. The bed's empty. He's surprised for a moment then remembers the argument the night before. He gets up. Sits on the edge of the bed. Lights a cigarette. He notices his jacket on the floor. Leans down. As he pulls out the BlackBerry from his jacket, the RING BOX falls onto the floor. Paul doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul steps into the kitchen. Nervously checking his BlackBerry. Nothing. Just then he sees the red light blinking on his answer machine. He presses play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? You home yet? Can you pick up?       I just don't want it to end like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's relieved. He picks up the phone.   Dials.   We hea the ringing on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two technicians, an OLD GUY and his YOUNG PALE ASSISTANT, push a NAKED BODY wrapped in plastic through the morgue. They jump as they hear the MUFFLED sound of a cell phone. The ringing comes from a bag speckled with blood lying on a table (we recognize it as Anna's bag). The Assistant walks over. Takes out the cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the schoolteacher's. From the car crash. Should I answer it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ringing stops abruptly.   It's suddenly very silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's in for a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times do I have to tell you? You can't leave their stuff laying around. It should've been returned to the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been busy, OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like she's really going to need her rollover minutes now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Assistant reaches for the bag, he notices a solitary shoe on the table. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall I do with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Assistant looks round. He can't see the other shoe anywhere. He turns to the Old Guy and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just burn it. You can't send them back one shoe. It's not respectful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it all wrong baby. I want you to come to Chicago with me. Look. I'll swing by your place on my way to the office. You know I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul pulls up to a suburban house. Walks quickly to the door, a supermarket bouquet of flowers wrapped in cellophane in his hand. He rings the bell. No-one answers. He rings again. Knocks hard on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still no answer. Paul looks around. Notices the driveway's empty. He heads back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. PAUL'S CAR
dialogues.text: Paul's on his cell phone as he drives.    He gets Anna's voice mail again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me again. I must have just missed you at home. Call me when you get this. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul strides down an empty corridor. The flowers in his hand. Searching for Anna's classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TEACHER stands in front of the class holding a shell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the shell grows slowly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Paul steps into the classroom.    His smile fades as he realizes it's not Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hi.   I'm looking for Anna Bryant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Teacher quickly moves over.    Hustles Paul to the do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but you just can't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Anna's... fiancГ©e. Paul Conran.     I thought this was her class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Teacher glances suspiciously at the flowers in his ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a little misunderstanding last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't come in today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's in the front row.   Following the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she call in sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hasn't called in at all. It's not like her. She always calls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's worried now.   Something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies rigidly on the slab. Her head turned to one side. Staring blankly at the wall. Her eyes glazed. Suddenly classical music fills the room. Anna frowns. Disoriented. She moves her head with difficulty. Nervously looks around. For a moment she doesn't know where she is. Then she sees Eliot by a CD player. She watches with trepidation as he approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I hurt you?     You're already dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna doesn't know what to say.   She turns her head away. A tear falls down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Just let me go. I won't go to the police. I won't tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot moves her head back.   Gently wipes away her tear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still in denial. You have to trust me. I'm only here to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot slides a wooden head-rest under her neck and studie her wounds, touching them delicately. Thinking about how to conceal them. He turns to a tray of instruments. Picks up a needle. Leans over Anna. The needle pierces her brow. Sliding cleanly through her skin. She doesn't feel any pain as Eliot carefully sews the wound. He's meticulous. Clearly very good at his job. Eliot glances at his watch. Picks up a SYRINGE and an AMPOULE OF AMBER LIQUID. Draws up the amber liquid. Anna's alarmed. She tries to pull back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will relax your muscles. Stop the rigor mortis setting in so I can work on your body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He INJECTS Anna in the neck. Just then we hear a car pull up on the gravel driveway outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother's early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's eyelids feel very heavy. Slowly her eyes close. Eliot pulls the white sheet over her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Nurse, DIANE (30s) follows Beatrice in her wheelchair as Eliot leads them through the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so very sorry Mrs. Bryant. It's always so tragic when you lose a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost her years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at her curiously.    Then gestures to his offi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd care to come to my office we can discuss the arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she hasn't been--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. I want to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes him a second to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice leans against the slab staring at Anna's covered body. Eliot stands respectfully to one side. In the b.g. Diane shivers. The room's cold. Beatrice touches Anna's hand through the white sheet. Then uncovers Anna's face. The needle's still embedded in her eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.   Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot quickly steps forward. Pulls out the needle.    Cut the thread with a pair of large scissors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said. I've only just started preparing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point of preserving the body if the soul's already left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to himself) No.   The soul never leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice stares at Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's us who are left behind. It's us who suffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to look after me now? Did you think about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods to Diane.    Diane helps her into the wheelchair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll confirm the date with Father Graham this afternoon. Friday as you requested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do what you think's best.   It's just details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice whirs towards the door.      She suddenly stops. Turns to Eliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh there is one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hair. She was a brunette.    I'd like it back to that color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot watches Beatrice's car drive away.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. PAUL'S CAR
dialogues.text: Paul waits in his car outside the Mother's house. wilting flowers on the passenger seat beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice's car pulls up. Diane gets out.      Pulls the wheelchair out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul grabs the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul strides over as Diane helps Beatrice into her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bryant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice doesn't acknowledge him.   Paul turns to Diane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Diane.   I need to talk to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diane can't look him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you better come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice sits in her wheelchair with her back to the door. Paul stops a short distance away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? Where's Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna was in a car accident last night. My daughter's dead. That's what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stares at Beatrice's back in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car crash?     When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice turns her wheelchair round to face Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said it happened just before 8.30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... we were at the restaurant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice glares at him.    She clearly blames him for Anna's death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have let her drive in that weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks down guiltily at the flowers in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She can't be dead.    There must be some mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no mistake. We just got back from the funeral home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice pushes a joystick on her wheelchair.   As she whirs past Paul she notices the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers? How appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's not listening anymore.   Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took her away from me.   I don't want you anywhere near her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot turns on the taps.   Fills a copper kettle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. O.S. a shuddering pipe bangs ominously. Anna opens her eyes abruptly as if waking from a deep sleep. She stares at us. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an exploding BLUE FLAME from a gas ring. We pull back. Eliot places a kettle on the ring. Then measures out exactly two spoons of tea from an ornate tin into a teapot. Meticulous in everything he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Anna's hand. Her fingers FLEX slightly. She pushes herself up awkwardly. Suddenly realizes something. She touches her wrist. Desperately searching for her pulse. Then frantically checks her neck. Panicking. She can't find her heartbeat. She stares at her hand. Then abruptly SLAMS it against the slab. Hard. She feels no pain. She does it again. Harder. Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must be in shock.     That's all.   It's just shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She struggles to her feet. Stumbles groggily to the door. Tries the door handle. It's locked. She bangs on the door feebly. Then she hears something. She cocks her head. Follows the sound of Eliot's footsteps upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot's by his desk. Checking his appointment book. Whistling softly to himself. We can't hear Anna's cries. He pours a cup of tea. Adds a drop of milk. As he stirs his tea, he hears the sound of feet CRUNCHING on the gravel outside. He glances out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stands in the middle of the driveway staring blankly at the Funeral Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot steps out of the Funeral Home.     Heads towards Pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul turns to him.   Pulled away from his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Conran.      Paul Conran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot smiles.    Holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. The lawyer. (off Paul's surprised look) It's a small town. In my line of work you get to know everyone eventually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they shake, Eliot looks at Paul's hand strangely.    A if he senses something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Anna Bryant's fiancГ©e.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's strange. She wasn't wearing an engagement ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well not quite fiancГ©e...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry for your loss Mr. Conran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid the viewing isn't until--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd need to see her now.    If that's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's not possible.     You're not family and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.   It'd only take a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO.   YOU DON'T UNDERSTAND!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna suddenly hears Paul's loud voice outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul! I'm here! Paul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She frantically beats her fists against the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul quickly controls his anger.    His eyes smart with t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to stop her.     She didn't hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's voice breaks with emotion. He can't go on. Eliot gently takes him by the elbow. Leads him back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran.  There really is nothing I can do. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks defeated. He simply nods his head.     Eliot watches him get into his car and drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits by the door in the darkness. Suddenly the room's flooded with light. Eliot walks in. Looks at Anna for a moment. She just stares back at him coldly. He heads over to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I heard you talking to him. Why didn't you let him see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot smiles. Amused she caught him out.   He continues washing his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you love him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks up sharply.   Eliot's clearly hit a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot shrugs.   Dries his hands on a white towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't going to tell me Paul was here, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it would only hurt you. You have to let go of the living. Just like they have to let go of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.   Why are you doing this to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head as he drops the towel into a small bin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all the same. You all blame me for your death. As if it were my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You drugged me.    So my mother

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others. They just see you as a dead body on a slab. Only I can see you as you really are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot's taken aback.    Hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a busy man. I don't have time for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads to the door. Pulls out his keys and unlocks it. Just then he remembers something. Turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I nearly forgot.    How tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks her up and down.   Gauging her height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to know how tall you are.   For your coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's stunned. Eliot looks at her for a moment.     Then switches off the main lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ignores her.   The door CLICKS shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot steps into the hallway. Stops by a vase of flowers. He plucks a dead petal. Crushes it. Curiously sniffs his fingers. Then heads to the casket room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Anna's face. She looks empty. Dispirited. Just then something catches her attention... The light from the window glints off a pair of LARGE SCISSORS on the steel trolley. Anna stumbles to the trolley. Feeling her way through the semi-darkness. Grabs the scissors. Just then she notices a BODY, covered with a white sheet, lying on a gurney in the corner. She turns away. Scared. But then, almost against her will, she approaches the gurney. As if drawn to the body. She slowly pulls the sheet away... The dead body of an OLD WOMAN. Staring blindly at Anna with cloudy opaque eyes. Long greasy gray hair. Shaken, Anna pushes herself against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God.   Please. I don't want to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack carefully cuts something out of a local newspaper. The loud sounds of a TV blare from another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schoolteacher Dies in Tragic Car Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn. JACK'S MOTHER sits in an armchair with her back to us watching TV. Jack walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were supposed to pick me up from school yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother doesn't reply.   Jack moves in front of the TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I waited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack furiously cycles through empty streets. Past identical suburban houses with identical prim lawns. He stops suddenly. Considering something. Then turns and cycles away purposely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot walks out of the funeral home. We pull back. Jack stands by his bicycle in the bushes watching him. Eliot looks up. As if sensing someone was spying on him. Jack steps back quickly behind a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE OFFICER talks on the phone as Paul walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on a sec.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran. Heard about your girlfriend. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul nods.    Clearly doesn't want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Tom in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain just stepped out. He won't be long. You can wait in his office if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.   I'll just go and grab a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul walks away, the Officer returns to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buddy of the captain's. Poor guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul slides a dollar bill into a coffee machine. Presses his selection. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the button repeatedly.   Then angrily slams the side of the machine. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul turns away, he notices a door with a sign on it: AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY. Paul glances around. Then quickly walks over to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen wrecked cars. Twisted metal. Paul's footsteps echo through the empty garage. It's dark. Out the corner of his eye Paul glimpses a SHAPE move quickly around a pillar. He stops. Unsettled. Just then we hear a WOMAN'S FOOTSTEPS. Her high-heels clicking on the concrete floor. There's something strange about the sound. UNNATURAL. Paul listens nervously. The footsteps grow fainter. Then fade away. The garage is silent again. Too quiet. Paul moves apprehensively over to Anna's GREEN TOYOTA. The car's a mess. One side's completely caved in. He touches the car.   Pulls open the door. Squeezes into the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glass everywhere. Paul glances at the KITSCHY BOBBLEHEAD DOLL on the dashboard flecked with blood. He places his hands on the steering wheel. Suddenly he hears a strange noise. He looks up... The KITSCHY DOLL. Its head NODDING SLOWLY. Its smiling face now unnaturally sinister. Turning towards us until it abruptly stops. Staring straight at us. Paul looks at the doll transfixed. Just then a PALE WOMAN'S HAND slowly reaches through the window... and touches Paul's shoulder. He jumps. Turns. ANNA stands by the car. Staring blankly at him.   The color drains from Paul's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Police Captain, Tom Peterson, stands by the car where Anna was a second ago. He pulls his hand away from Paul's shoulder. Looks at him with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul gathers his composure. He must have just imagined Anna was there. He shoves the door open. He's about to step out when he turns back and grabs the Kitschy Doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul gets out awkwardly.    He can't look Tom in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just found out. I'm so sorry Paul.       If you need anything--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral director won't let me see her Tom. He says I'm not family. Can you talk to him? Put some pressure on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom.    You're my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul.     I can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul nods slowly.    Tom notices the Kitschy Doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you're OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul. It was an accident. You should get some rest. Let me drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always fuck everything up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot stops by a thermostat. Studies it for a moment. Turns it lower. He glances at his watch. Takes out his keys from his jacket and moves over to the Prep Room door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits on the slab. Her hands behind her back.    She carefully watches Eliot as he pulls on his pale blue smock then walks over to a cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND ANNA'S BACK
dialogues.text: her hands clutch the large scissors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot opens a cabinet full of boxes of hair dye with photographs of smiling women. As he prepares the dye he looks across at Anna. She's staring at something behind him. Eliot turns. Sees the uncovered body of the Old Woman on the gurney. He quickly walks over. Carefully pulls the white sheet over the Old Woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitehall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mixes the dye in a bowl as he moves over to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be afraid of her.   The dead can't harm the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's hand suddenly FLIES UP...   she slashes at Eliot's face with the SCISSORS. The sharp edge misses his cheek by inches. Eliot drops the bowl. Stumbles back against the steel trolley. Instruments crash to the floor. Anna staggers to the door. Her legs weak. Her long lank hair falling over her eyes. She frantically wrenches at the door handle but it's locked. Eliot gets up. Slowly moves towards Anna. She turns. Raises the scissors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay where you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds out his hand) Give me the scissors. I only want to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come any closer.     I swear to God I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot walks right up to her.     His face now inches from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna doesn't move. Eliot looks her steadily in the eye. He reaches for her hand. Slowly. Deliberately. He brings the scissors to his cheek. Then lets go of Anna's hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT'S FACE
dialogues.text: The sharp tip pushes into his skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment we think she might do it.      But then she

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's confidence falters. She slowly lowers her hand. The scissors fall onto the floor. Anna looks down defeated. Her breath labored. Suddenly she realizes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm breathing! (raises her head) Look. I'm still alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're still alive because you're still attached to life. It's normal. You're just imagining you still have symptoms of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not listening. Eliot takes a roll of paper towels. Kneels down, picks up the bowl of dye and mops up the mes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I was in some kind of coma. The doctors made a mistake. They're always making mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You died.   Everyone dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I be dead if we're talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up.    Sighs wearily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're talking not because you're alive. But because I have a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can talk to those between life and death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To help them make the transition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's stunned. For the first time we sense a seed of doubt in her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what happens when you die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on how you lived your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everyone needs my help. Some let go as soon as their body dies. Others don't let go until long after they're in the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I a ghost? Is that why I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here so I can bury you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's silent. Trying to make sense of what she's just heard. Eliot takes her arm. Leads her to the slab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.    We've wasted enough time already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lies down submissively. Suddenly very tired.       El leans over her to apply what's left of the dye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    Please. I don't want--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a corpse. Your opinion doesn't count anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can breathe.     I must be alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She weakly pushes him away. Anger flashes across Eliot's face, but just as quickly he controls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people. You all think that if you breathe, shit, piss you're alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You clutch onto life as if your life was worth clutching onto. Was your life worth clutching onto Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns her head away.   Clearly he's struck a chord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it?   Maybe you died a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot rips off his latex gloves.    Tosses them into a bi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you I'm surprised you're still arguing with me. You don't have much time left. (gestures to the Old Women) Look. She's accepted her death. Her life has been examined. She has no more regrets. And now she's at peace. She used her time well. You still have so much to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to learn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot stands in the doorway. He switches off the light. His body silhouetted by the light from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your funeral's in three days. Soon you'll be enclosed in a coffin. Then buried in the ground. No-one will hear you then. No-one will talk to you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door clicks shut behind him. Anna doesn't move. Clearly unsettled by Eliot's words. After a moment she looks at the Old Woman. She moves over. Hesitantly pulls away the white sheet. Stares at the Old Woman curiously. Then tentatively touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the Old Woman's hand.      Strokes her paper-th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna notices the Old Woman's plastic ankle tag.

dialogues.speaker: ON PLASTIC ANKLE TAG
dialogues.text: Name: Carol Whitehall.     Sex: F.   DOB: 11.02.30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a long life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns back.   Studies the Old Woman's serene face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look so peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared.    I'm so scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lies in bed staring at the ceiling. On his bedside table an alarm clock reads 2.38AM. He looks across at an Anglepoise lamp in the corner of the room bent over an op shoebox. He gets up. Walks towards the muted light. The SMALL CHICK huddles in the shoebox. It looks dead eve though it's eyes are open. Jack's about to reach into the box. Then changes his mind. He looks at the lamp. Switche it off. After a moment he switches it back on again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stands motionless in the middle of the room. Staring blankly into space. The room feels empty and depressing. He suddenly looks around. Not quite sure why he came into the room in the first place. He moves over to a CD player Mechanically switches it on. Music fills the room. He turns the volume higher. Then all the way up. The music's unbearably loud but Paul just stands there. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music's strangely distorted now.        Almost silent if we were inside Paul's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies on the slab. Curled in a fetal position. O.S. we hear the UNNATURALLY LOUD metallic drip of a faulty faucet. Slow. Rhythmical. Anna opens her eyes. Stares at us. Terrified. Then she turns her head. The Old Woman sits on the other slab. Slowly brushing her tangled gray hair with a silver backed brush. Anna looks around anxiously. The room is strangely larger. The perspective not quite right. Certain objects look absurdly small or abnormally large. She notices a TINY DOOR. Half hidden by a steel trolley. The door's slightly ajar. Anna's surprised. The Old Woman shakes her head. Staring blindly at Anna with opaque eyes. Anna ignores her. Moves quickly to the tiny door. As she approaches, the door seems to grow to normal size. Then we realize it's Anna who has shrunk. The steel trolley now towers high above her. The massive instruments on the trolley look like menacing insects cast in surgical steel. She opens the door. Revealing a solid wall of DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: FROM INSIDE THE DARKNESS
dialogues.text: the small shape of Anna in the doorway. The huge dark space engulfs her. The only light comes from the Prep Room behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna reaches forward. Her hand disappears into the thick blackness. She snatches her hand back. Scared. Then... ...a CHILD'S HAND darts out of the darkness. Grabs Anna's wrist. Pulling her in with surprising strength. Anna struggles to free herself. But the hand drags her deeper into the darkness. The door slams shut behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna stands in the black empty space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm disappointed with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An innocent looking YOUNG GIRL (6) materializes out of the blackness. She looks like a young Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Girl walks slowly towards Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised me so many things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't recognize me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am you. I've been waiting for you. You shouldn't have disappointed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girl now looks strangely malevolent. Anna steps back terrified. Turns. But there's no door anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Woman stands alone in the middle of the room. Braiding her long hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small congregation of MOURNERS sit in the white chairs. "AVE MARIA" plays quietly in the b.g. A MAN leans over the casket paying his respects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Woman.   Her long hair braided.   She looks seren

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "AVE MARIA" filters into the room. Anna opens her eyes. She's confused. She gets up awkwardly. Looks around the room. The other slab's empty. The Old Woman's gone. Anna stumbles over to the trolley. Pushes it aside. Desperately searching for the tiny door. She touches the wall. There's nothing there. Frustrated she turns to a counter crowded with instruments. She sweeps her arm across the counter top in rage. Sending everything crashing to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral's over. Eliot takes out a wilted bouquet of flowers from a vase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. Jack stands half-hidden in the doorway. Glancing around in fascination. A flower in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack without looking up) Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps back timidly.   Eliot looks up.   Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then perhaps you can help me. (holds up the withered flowers) Could you throw these away for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack nods hesitantly.   Moves over and takes the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank-you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot turns and arranges fresh flowers in the vase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he looks at the wilted flowers.    He crushes a petal then sniffs his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no life left in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks up.   Eliot's watching him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They belong in the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen you round here before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's suddenly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know Mrs. Whitehall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was Miss Bryant's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Miss Bryant. No.       Her funeral's not until Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot considers the question for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Because she's not ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the flower for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was my teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack holds out his hand. A serious look on his face. Eliot's amused. He shakes Jack's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Jack.      What did you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
